Monday, January 5, 1852.
At 12 o'clock, the appointed hour, the South-western
Railroad Convention assembled in the Lyceum Hall ofthe
Second Municipality.
Maiwsel White, as President of the New Orleans and
Opelousas Railroad Convention, called the assemblage
to order, and in doing so, addressed the meeting as
follows :
Gentlemen, Delegates from, our sister States.- We tender you a cordial
and hearty welcome. We recoguise you as friends and brothers, come amongst
lis hy special invitation, to deliberate on a matter worthy of American enterprise, in which all the Southwestern States are deeply interested.
Our design offers abundant inducement for the ready co-operatiou of all
who may houor us with their attention.
Viewed as public undertaking, the whole Union must acknowledge their
importance; and even in the smaller consideration of individual interests,
perhaps there never were roads contemplated of higher promise.
Now, gentlemen, it will be for you to choose and elect the officers whom you
desire to preside over this Convention, as we feel ourselves bound in courtesy
to yield you that privilege, confident that in the exercise of this duty, you will
oe actuated by the sole desire of doing ample and even-handed justice to all
the various interests that may be involved.
this friendly meeting of representatives of popular interest for the common
consideration of so profound a question, is'entirely in accordance witlrthe
Ulaacter of our age and day; and we sincerely trust, gentlemen, that the
rcsult of our deliberations will be equally compatible with the all-accomplishing
genius of our country.
£gam, gentlemen, we bid you welcome.
meeting is now prepared for organization. May He, who alone presides
n unquestionable wusdoni, bless and direct yourproceedings.

«uded the business of the Opelousas Railroad Convention
0 auspiciously commenced in June—the hopes of its friends
urmed, their confidence in its success established.
MAUNSEL WHITE, President.
ENJ. F. Flanders, Secretary.
